cc.text: Book report on "Last Child in the Woods"

In "Last Child in the Woods", Richard Louv expounds his personal belief that exposure to nature is a critical factor to a healthy childhood. The book as a whole is a bit of a muddle, because it touches on too many different subjects, and several chapters don't speak about children at all.

Regardless, I find the central ideas convincing: that children need nature for both physical and emotional health, and that the long-term health of the planet depends on children actually experiencing nature and developing a personal belief in its value. (The latter as opposed to merely being taught about the destruction of faraway ecosystems, which may ultimately only instill despondence. Louv cogently argues how this perversely can lead to indifference rather than activism.)

Although there is room for optimism, as Louv points out in the second half of the book, the situation painted in the first half is decidedly bleak: children spend less and less time in nature, parents are increasingly afraid of letting children spend time experiencing nature on their own terms, and laws and regulations that are not explicitly intended to curb children's interaction with nature nevertheless more and more often have that effect.

What can we do as parents? Avoid indoor playgrounds, bring our children outdoors, both into the mountains and into the city, and trust our children as well as our neighborhoods. Although that's hardly a new message, it is one worth reading again.
